<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>CLOSURE PROPERTY</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>Kendall, Montana</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify; color: #1F497D">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Kendall is located approximately 20 miles
north of Lewistown, Montana. Kendall was developed as an open-pit, heap-leach 
gold mine that operated from 1988 to its closure
in 1995. Leaching of the remaining gold in the heap-leach pads continued through
early 1998. Kendall produced approximately 302,000
ounces of gold and 136,000 ounces of silver from 1988 through 1998.&nbsp; 
Kendall operated under permits issued by Montana Department
of Environmental Quality (MDEQ) and other regulatory agencies. The Kendall 
permit area covers approximately 1,040 acres of which
approximately 448 acres were disturbed.&nbsp;Leach pad capping and surface 
reclamation and re-vegetation of the site are substantially
completed. Water management and treatment at the site will be continued for the 
foreseeable future.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">In April 2012, Kendall entered into an
agreement with the MDEQ, whereby Atna agreed to provide financial support to 
complete a final EIS closure study. As part of this
agreement, Kendall submitted on July 25, 2012 an application to the MDEQ 
providing a final closure and reclamation plan for the
Kendall mine site. In October 2014, Atna was advised by the MDEQ that it has 
reviewed the Kendall Mine&rsquo;s amended Closure
and Water Management Plan Application and has determined that the amendment 
application is complete and complies with substantive
requirements of the Metal Mine Reclamation Act, relying on the environmental 
analysis provided in the Kendall amendment application.
Based on this determination, the MDEQ has issued a draft permit amendment. The 
MDEQ has awarded a contract to an independent engineering
firm to write the environmental analysis for the draft and final Environmental 
Impact Study (&ldquo;EIS&rdquo;) to support the
final closure plan. Work on the EIS commenced in March 2015 and a draft EIS 
study is expected to be completed in 2015.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">CR Kendall has approximately $2.4 million
on deposit in an interest-bearing account with the MDEQ for reclamation work at 
Kendall. A further $0.2 million surety bond is
also in place. Once a final Record of Decision on the Plan has been issued by 
the MDEQ, as part of the amended agreement, CRK
will use any cash remaining on deposit with the MDEQ to fund any future 
operation, maintenance and replacement of water treatment
and closure facilities. All facilities required to implement the amended plan, 
consisting primarily of long-term water treatment
facilities, are in place.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As reclamation objectives at Kendall are
achieved, parcels of land are being made available for purchase to the general 
public. From 2010 through 2014, Kendall has sold
or donated a total of 598.2 acres of reclaimed and natural land parcels in a 
number of transactions. Kendall retains the water
rights associated with the sold parcels as well as rights-of-access to conduct 
environmental monitoring and additional reclamation,
if required.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 17; Value: 1 -->
    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt 
solid"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 100%">-
<!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->17<!-- Field: /Sequence -->-
</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>

    <!-- Field: /Page -->
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    <TD><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S 
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New

    June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Regulatory agencies must give final approval
to all closure measures and be satisfied that the mine has met all reclamation 
requirements.&nbsp; There is no assurance of agency
satisfaction with mine closure. Kendall uses internal and external technical and
legal experts to monitor and ensure environmental
compliance. Atna believes the operation is currently in material compliance with
all environmental and safety regulations.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>Summary of Mineral Reserves and
Resources</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The mineral reserve and resource figures
below are estimates, subject to forward-looking-statement limitations. All 
reserve and resource figures are considered current
as indicated in the footnotes to the tables. The scientific and technical 
information about the Company&rsquo;s mineral properties
contained in this Report has been prepared under the supervision of, reviewed by
and approved by William Stanley, a Registered
Member of the Society for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration, a Licensed 
Geologist, the Company's Vice President Exploration,
a &ldquo;qualified person&rdquo; as that term is defined in NI 43-101.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The mineral resources reported below,
other than those declared as proven and probable mineral reserves, have no 
demonstrated economic viability at this time. The quantity
and grade of reported inferred mineral resources in these estimations are based 
on limited information and should be considered
conceptual in nature. It is uncertain if further exploration will result in 
discovery of a measured or indicated mineral resource
within those areas classified as inferred resources.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">An NI 43-101 Technical Report and Pre-Feasibility
Study on the Pinson property titled &ldquo;NI 43-101 Technical Report, Pinson 
Project, Preliminary Feasibility Study, Humboldt
County, Nevada&rdquo; dated October 17, 2014 with an effective date of June 30, 
2014 (the &ldquo;Pinson Technical Report&rdquo;)
was endorsed by Richard E. Kiel, PE, Edward H. Minnes, PE, and Russ Browne, PE, 
all of Golder Associates Inc., Joseph M. Keane,
PE of SGS Metcon/KD Engineering, Donald E. Hulse, P.E. of Gustavson Associates, 
LLC and Mark A. Odell, PE, and Karl T. Swanson,
SME, MAusIMM, of Practical Mining LLC. The Company is currently mining the new 
underground reserve and progressively ramping-up
production levels. Additional permitting is required to commence development of 
the open pit reserves at the project.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-
align: justify">Cautionary Note to US Investors concerning
estimates of Measured and Indicated Resources: This section uses the terms 
&ldquo;measured&rdquo; and &ldquo;indicated&rdquo;
mineral resources. The Company advises US investors that while those terms are 
recognized and required by Canadian regulations,
the US Securities and Exchange Commission (the &ldquo;SEC&rdquo;) does not 
recognize them. US investors are cautioned not to assume
that any part or all of mineral resources in these categories will ever be 
converted into reserves.</P>
<P STYLE="font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-
align: justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>Cautionary Note to US Investors concerning
estimates of Inferred Resources: This section uses the term 
&ldquo;inferred&rdquo; mineral resources. The Company advises US investors
that while this term is recognized and required by Canadian regulations, the SEC
does not recognize it. &ldquo;Inferred&rdquo;
mineral resources have a great amount of uncertainty as to their existence, and 
great uncertainty as to their economic and legal
feasibility. It cannot be assumed that all or any part of an inferred mineral 
resource will ever be upgraded to a higher category.
Under Canadian rules, estimates of inferred mineral resources may not form the 
basis of feasibility or pre-feasibility studies,
except in rare cases. US investors are cautioned not to assume that part or all 
of an inferred resource exists, or is economically
or legally minable.</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 
0"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>

align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.1in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 
0.25in"><B><I><SUP>(1)</SUP></I></B></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Briggs
                                         mineral reserve summary is based on a 
0.0069 opt gold incremental leach cut-off grade
                                         calculated using $1,300 per ounce gold 
supported by the report titled &ldquo;2012 NI
                                         43-101 Technical Report on the Briggs 
Mine, Inyo County, California&rdquo; dated May
                                         29, 2012 with an effective date of 
March 26, 2012 (the &ldquo;Briggs Report&rdquo;) prepared
                                         by Alan C. Noble, P.E. of Ore Reserves 
Engineering, Michael J. Read, SME-RM of Chlumsky,
                                         Armbrust &amp; Meyer LLC, William R. 
Stanley, SME-RM, V.P. Exploration of the Company,
                                         and Douglas E. Stewart, P.E., former 
V.P. and COO of the Company. Messrs. Noble and Read
                                         are independent qualified persons in 
accordance with NI 43-101 and Messrs. Stanley and
                                         Stewart are non-independent qualified 
persons in accordance with NI 43-101. The Briggs
                                         Report was filed on SEDAR on May 22, 
2012. The mineral reserve has been updated and reconciled
                                         by Mr. Read for mine production through
2014 and is current as of December 31, 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 
0"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>Summary of Quarterly Results </I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Following is selected quarterly financial
information for the eight most recent quarters. The information is reported in 
USD, in accordance with IFRS, consistently applied.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White">
    <TD STYLE="text-indent: -0.1in; padding-left: 16.2pt">Basic income per 
share</TD><TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="text-align: left">$</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: 
right">0.02</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: left">&nbsp;</TD><TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="text-align: left">$</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: right">-</TD><TD 
STYLE="text-align: left">&nbsp;</TD><TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="text-align: left">$</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: 
right">(0.25</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: left">)</TD><TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="text-align: left">$</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: 
right">(0.01</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: left">)</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The Company&rsquo;s financial results
are not significantly impacted by seasonality. Expenses and income vary 
depending on gold price; the tons of ore mined and processed;
ore grades; stripping ratios; labor, diesel, chemical, tire, aggregate, and 
maintenance costs; contract mining and processing
costs; gains and losses on derivatives; gains or losses on the sale of 
investments and disposals of properties; and other factors.
Significant operating costs include: labor and benefits, fuel, maintenance and 
supplies, chemicals, explosives, and outside services.
Competition for experienced mining staff continues to be an issue and has been a
factor in increasing the costs of doing business.
Regulatory costs have also been a factor in increasing the costs of doing 
business, particularly in California. Fuel cost is a
significant cost factor at Briggs. In First Half 2015, diesel fuel represented 
approximately 9 percent of Briggs&rsquo; &ldquo;Cost
of sales, excluding depreciation&rdquo;, while in 2014 and 2013, diesel fuel 
represented approximately 23 percent and 22 percent
of &ldquo;Cost of sales, excluding depreciation&rdquo;, respectively. The 
decrease in diesel costs in First Half 2015 reflects
the lower price for fuel, but also shorter haul cycles and fewer total tons 
mined, given the cessation of pre-stripping activities,
at Briggs.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 23; Value: 1 -->
    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt
solid"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 100%">-
<!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->23<!-- Field: /Sequence -->-
</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>
    <DIV STYLE="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 
12pt"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 
100%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif"><B>ATNA RESOURCES LTD.</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Gold price trends indicated above reflect
global market conditions. In the last three years, the London PM Fix price per 
ounce of gold has been between $1,081 (July 2015)
and $1,792 (October 2012). The three-year average London PM Fix price at 
December 31, 2014 was $1,449. The range of price movements
in First Half 2015 was between $1,147 and $1,296 per ounce, with the average 
London PM Fix price being $1,206 per ounce.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Ounces sold relate directly to operating
capacity and production. In First Half 2015 and in 2014, production was 
principally impacted by ramping-up operations at Pinson
Underground, operations having recommenced in June 2014; the ramp-down and 
cessation of mining activities at Briggs; changes in
mined ore grades; and managing the crushing-plant bottleneck at Briggs. 
Additionally in 2014, production was principally impacted
by the degree and timing of stripping activities at Briggs. Mining and 
production metrics are discussed further under &ldquo;Briggs
Mine, California&rdquo; and &ldquo;Pinson Underground&rdquo; under &ldquo;Pinson
Mine Property, Nevada&rdquo; above.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Changes in the total cost of sales, excluding
depreciation, have generally been consistent with changes in the ounces sold. 
Gold ounces sold increased 13 percent in Second
Quarter 2015 relative to First Quarter 2015; cost of sales, excluding
depreciation, increased 18 percent; and the cost per ounce
increased 4 percent, reflecting, despite cost reductions, fixed costs being 
spread over fewer ounces at Briggs and certain inefficiencies
at Pinson associated with the ramp-up of operations, as discussed above. In 
First Quarter 2015, gold ounces sold decreased 9 percent;
cost of sales, excluding depreciation, decreased 4 percent; and the cost per 
ounce increased 6 percent, for reasons similar to
those indicated for Second Quarter 2015. In Fourth Quarter 2014 the cost per 
ounce decreased 6 percent, reflecting cost reductions
at Pinson and Briggs. In Third Quarter 2014 and in Second Quarter 2014, the 
average cost per gold ounce sold increased only marginally,
1 percent. The average cost per gold ounce increased 6 percent in First Quarter 
2014 as fixed costs and increases in maintenance
and other operating costs at Briggs were spread over fewer ounces sold than in 
Fourth Quarter 2013. The Goldtooth South pit had
a higher stripping ratio and involved longer haul-cycles than did the Briggs 
Main North or Briggs Main pits, causing increased
mining costs between May 2013 and October 2014. The average cost per gold ounce 
declined significantly in both the third and fourth
quarters of 2013 due to increased ore production and lower stripping ratios than
experienced earlier in 2013. </P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">See &ldquo;Results of Operations &ndash;
Year Ended December 31, 2014 versus Year Ended December 31, 2013&rdquo; later in
this MD&amp;A for descriptions of the write-downs
in inventory to estimated net realizable value and for descriptions of 
impairments recognized.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Depreciation and amortization within cost
of sales is initially calculated on a units-of-production basis. Depreciation 
expense per ounce has tended to increase as stripping,
equipment rebuilds, sustaining capital, and other capital additions at Briggs 
have been depreciated over a reserve being depleted
at a proportionally more rapid pace. There has been an increasing inconsistency 
on a depreciation-per-ounce basis between quarters
after June of 2013 as adjustments reducing the value of inventory to net 
realizable value decrease the depreciation within inventory
and hence decrease the depreciation expense that flows through cost of 
sales.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">General and administrative (&ldquo;G&amp;A&rdquo;)
expenses decreased $0.1 million or 13 percent in Second Quarter 2015 relative to
First Quarter 2015 through cost reductions offsetting
increases in First Quarter 2015. G&amp;A expenses in First Quarter 2015 had 
increased $0.1 million or 9 percent due largely to
&lsquo;one-off&rsquo; expenses for computer repairs, consultants, and legal 
services. Managed cost reductions reduced general
and administrative (&ldquo;G&amp;A&rdquo;) expenses in 2014, with the greatest 
impact being in the last two quarters. G&amp;A
expenses were relatively consistent between quarters in 2013.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align:
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 24; Value: 1 -->
    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt 
solid"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 100%">-
<!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->24<!-- Field: /Sequence -->-
</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>
    <DIV STYLE="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 
12pt"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 
100%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif"><B>ATNA RESOURCES LTD.</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Exploration expenses vary directly with
projects undertaken and the degree of certainty of future benefit. Only the 
maintenance of exploration claims were undertaken
in First Half 2015 and Fourth Quarter 2014. In Third Quarter 2014, $0.3 million 
of &lsquo;exploration&rsquo; expenses associated
with Pinson&rsquo;s pre-feasibility studies were capitalized upon the successful
completion of those studies. In the first and
second quarters of 2014, a pre-feasibility study was underway for the Mag Pit 
project at Pinson. In the third and fourth quarters
of 2013, leaching tests and geological and pre-feasibility studies were being 
conducted for the Mag Pit at Pinson.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Property-maintenance expenses depend on
activities at properties on a care and maintenance status. Pinson Underground 
was on care and maintenance between June of 2013
and June of 2014 when operations re-commenced. The Reward property, a 
development stage property, was considered to have been
on care and maintenance in 2014, prior to its sale in November of 2014.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align:
justify">The Company recognized site restoration
expense of $0.7 million in 2014 and a site restoration recovery of $0.6 million 
in 2013. The expense recognized in 2014 resulted
primarily from an updated time table for reclamation work at Briggs and a change
in estimated future costs at Kendall. In 2013,
estimated future Briggs reclamation costs were decreased, leading to the 
recovery.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Largely due to a partial pre-payment of
debt amounting to $4.9 million in Fourth Quarter 2014, interest expense declined
15 percent to $1.0 million in Second Quarter
2015 and in First Quarter 2015. On January 31, 2014, the Company entered into a 
$22.0 million credit facility agreement (the &ldquo;Waterton
Loan&rdquo;) with Waterton Precious Metals Fund II Cayman, LP 
(&ldquo;Waterton&rdquo;). Interest expense was consistently between
$1.2 million and $1.3 million in each quarter of 2014, principally being 
incurred or imputed on the Waterton Loan. The Waterton
Loan refinanced other current obligations and the C$18.1 million balance of a 
note (&ldquo;Sprott Loan&rdquo;) with Sprott Resource
Lending Partnership (&ldquo;Sprott&rdquo;), initially undertaken in 2011 to 
finance the initial development and acquisition of
the remaining 70 percent interest in Pinson. Interest expense includes accretion
of asset retirement obligations, loan discount-fee
amortization, and interest for equipment financing. In Fourth Quarter 2013, $1.1
million of loan-amendment fees, related to the
Sprott Loan replaced in January of 2014, was written-off as interest expense, 
adding to the $1.0 million of interest expense otherwise
recognized that quarter. When Pinson Underground was placed on care and 
maintenance at the end of June 2013, interest incurred
began to be expensed, increasing interest expense to $1.0 million in Third 
Quarter 2013. When debt, including existing general
corporate debt, is used to fund material capital projects such as the 
development of the Pinson mine, accounting guidance (IFRS)
requires the related interest on the debt to be capitalized as part of the cost 
of the project.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The minimal unrealized gains and loss
on derivatives in 2014 resulted from mark-to-market accounting for open forward 
sales at the quarter-ends. Realized and unrealized
gains and losses on derivatives prior to December 31, 2013 relate directly to 
market movements in the price of gold and the embedded
forward sales in the 2009 Gold Bonds, which were retired in December of 
2013.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Other expense and income indicate the
impact of &lsquo;one-off&rsquo; events. In First Quarter 2015, a $0.4 million 
loss was recognized on the sale of a redundant haul
truck. In Fourth Quarter 2014, the $1.3 million expense principally reflects the
$1.1 million book-loss on the sale of CR Reward
Corp. and the Clover Property. In the First Quarter 2014, the $2.4 million 
income principally reflects the $2.3 million foreign-exchange
gain realized upon the settlement of the Sprott Loan, denominated in Canadian
dollars. In 2013, other income was principally realized
on insurance settlements for claims filed in 2013 and in 2012.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Income tax benefits and expenses recorded
relate to the current year&rsquo;s results, to the deferred tax provision 
related to changes in longer-term projections, and to
updates in the expected use of the Company&rsquo;s deferred net operating 
losses. During 2013, the Company updated and recognized
reductions of $10.3 million in its deferred tax assets (&ldquo;DTA&rdquo;) 
attributable to its US net operating loss carryforwards
and all other sources. Until the timing and magnitude of future taxable profits 
became clearer, the Company determined that there
was not a sufficient probability that future taxable profits would be available 
to utilize tax loss carryforwards and deductible
temporary differences.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 25; Value: 1 -->
    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 
0"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 
0"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"><B><I>Results
of Operations &ndash; Second Quarter 2015 versus
Second Quarter 2014</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align:
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Atna recognized a net loss of $9.4 million,
$(0.04) per basic share, for the Second Quarter 2015. These quarterly results 
compare to a net loss of $3.0 million, $(0.02) per
basic share, for the Second Quarter 2014. Significant elements of the $6.4<B> 
</B>million increased loss between the two quarters
are presented below, however the change principally resulted from recognition of
impairments at Briggs in the amount of $3.1 million
and the write-down of work-in-progress gold inventories to net realizable value,
amounting to $3.0 million.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Gold
                                         and silver revenues increased $0.1 
million, or 1 percent, to $10.9 million in Second
                                         Quarter 2015 compared to Second Quarter
2014 with the gold ounces sold increasing from
                                         8,301 ounces to 9,116 ounces, a 10 
percent increase, and the average price realized per
                                         gold ounce sold decreasing from $1,297 
to $1,203, a 7 percent decrease.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Cost
                                         of sales, excluding depreciation, and 
excluding adjustments to inventory valuations,
                                         was $10.2 million in Second Quarter 
2015 and $8.8 million in Second Quarter 2014, an
                                         increase of $1.4 million, or 16 
percent. Ounces sold increased 10 percent, so a net 6
                                         percent increase relates to per unit 
costs. The 6 percent increase largely followed from
                                         fixed costs being spread over fewer 
produced ounces at Briggs and certain inefficiencies
                                         discussed within the &ldquo;Pinson 
Underground&rdquo; section of this report.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: 
justify">Depreciation,
                                         cost of sales, was $2.1 million in 
Second Quarter 2015 and $2.0 million in Second Quarter
                                         2014. Depreciation expense was actually
increasing more significantly, but the write-downs
                                         of inventory to estimated net 
realizable value in prior quarters reduced the depreciation
                                         flowing out of inventory and into cost 
of sales. With the suspension of mining activities
                                         at Briggs in July of 2015 and with the 
Briggs Main North Pit being depleted and written-off
in Second Quarter 2015, depreciation 
expense should materially decline in the coming
                                         quarters.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">A
                                         write-down of inventory to estimated 
net realizable value less costs of completion resulted
                                         in recognition of an expense of $3.0 
million in Second Quarter 2015 and a recovery of
                                         $0.1 million in Second Quarter 2014. 
The adjustments were based on the quarter-end gold
                                         prices of $1,171 and $1,315 per ounce 
of gold, respectively.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">General
                                         and administrative expenses declined by
28 percent from $1.1 million to under $0.8 million
                                         in Second Quarter 2015, relative to 
Second Quarter 2014. This reflects the results of
                                         cost reduction 
efforts.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         Second Quarter 2015, impairments of 
$3.1 million were recognized. Impairments consisted
                                         of: $2.0 million for the balance of 
deferred pre-stripping of the Briggs Main North Pit,
                                         upon its depletion; $1.0 million 
estimated for the write-down to market value of idled
                                         mining equipment to be sold; and $0.1 
for the balance of stripping activity assets associated
                                         with the Briggs Main North 
Pit.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Exploration
                                         expenses declined from $0.2 million to 
$0.1 million reflecting reduced exploration activities.
                                         Expenditures were principally for the 
maintenance of exploration claims in both quarters.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Care
                                         and maintenance expenses declined from 
$0.3 million to virtually nil in Second Quarter
                                         2015, relative to Second Quarter 2014,
reflecting that no properties remained on care-and-
maintenance.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Interest
                                         expense decreased by $0.2 million to 
$1.0 million in Second Quarter 2015, principally
                                         as $4.9 million of debt was voluntarily
pre-paid in Fourth Quarter 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Losses
                                         on asset disposals and unrealized 
losses on derivatives were immaterial in Second Quarter
                                         2015, and were $0.3 million and $0.1 
million, respectively in Second Quarter 2014. The
                                         loss on the disposition of assets of 
$0.3 million in Second Quarter 2014 principally
                                         resulted from the sale of an idle rock 
crusher at the Pinson property.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.6in; 
text-align: justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As of June 30, 2015, cash and cash equivalents
were $1.1 million; the cash balance having decreased $0.5 million in the Second 
Quarter 2015. The significant elements underlying
the net decrease of $0.5 million are presented below with comparisons to Second 
Quarter 2014.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 26; Value: 1 -->
    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt 
solid"><TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 100%">-

</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>

Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><TR><TD STYLE="text-align: center; width: 
100%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE></DIV>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Symbol; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif"><B>ATNA RESOURCES LTD.</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Symbol; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Net
                                         cash provided by operating activities 
was $0.6 million in Second Quarter 2015 and $1.4
                                         million in Second Quarter 2014. $1.1 
million less cash was attributable to operating
                                         results and working capital changes 
provided $0.3 million of additional cash, offsetting
                                         a portion of the decrease. The 7 
percent decline in gold prices and the 6 percent increase
                                         in cost of sales, excluding 
depreciation, per unit were the principal drivers of the
                                         decreased cash flow from operations in 
Second Quarter 2015.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">$0.3
                                         million was spent for mine development 
at Pinson in Second Quarter 2015. In Second Quarter
                                         2014, $1.5 million was spent for 
stripping of the North Main Pit and $0.1 million was
                                         spent for equipment rebuilds at 
Briggs.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Nil
                                         and $0.2 million were spent for 
stripping activity assets at Briggs in Second Quarter
                                         2015 and Second Quarter 2014, 
respectively.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Proceeds
                                         from the sale of miscellaneous assets 
provided $0.1 million in Second Quarter 2015 and
                                         $0.4 million in Second Quarter 
2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         Second Quarter 2015, $0.9 million of 
cash was used to service finance leases and notes,
                                         whereas $1.1 million was used for this 
in Second Quarter 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.5in; 
text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.25in">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0"><B><I>Results
of Operations &ndash; First Half 2015 versus
First Half 2014</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Atna recognized a net loss of $14.5 million,
$(0.07) per basic share, for the First Half 2015. This compares to a net loss of
$3.9 million, $(0.02) per basic share, for the
First Half 2014. Significant elements of the $10.6<B> </B>million increased loss
between the semi-annual periods are presented
below.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Gold
                                         and silver revenues increased $0.2 
million, or 1 percent, to $20.8 million in First Half
                                         2015 compared to the First Half 2014 
with the gold ounces sold increasing from 16,071
                                         ounces to 17,199 ounces, a 7 percent 
increase, and the average price realized per gold
                                         ounce sold decreasing 5 percent from 
$1,276 to $1,212.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Cost
                                         of sales, excluding depreciation, and 
excluding impairments and adjustments to inventory
                                         valuations, was $18.8 million in First 
Half 2015 and $16.9 million in First Half 2014,
                                         an increase of $1.9 million, or 11 
percent. Ounces sold increased 7 percent, so a net
                                         4 percent increase relates to per unit 
costs. The 4 percent increase largely followed
                                         from fixed costs being spread over 
fewer produced ounces at Briggs and certain inefficiencies
                                         discussed within the &ldquo;Pinson 
Underground&rdquo; section of this report.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align:
justify">Depreciation,
                                         cost of sales, was $3.9 million in 
First Half 2015 and $3.7 million in First Half 2014.
                                         Depreciation expense was actually 
increasing more significantly, but the write-downs
                                         of inventory to estimated net 
realizable value in prior quarters reduced the depreciation
                                         flowing out of inventory and into cost 
of sales. With the suspension of mining activities
                                         at Briggs in July of 2015 and with the 
Briggs Main North Pit being depleted and written-off
                                         in Second Quarter 2015, depreciation 
expense should materially decline in the coming
                                         quarters.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Write-downs
                                         of inventory to estimated net 
realizable value less costs of completion resulted in recognition
                                         of $5.5 million in expense in First 
Half 2015 and $0.3 million in First Half 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">General
                                         and administrative expenses declined by
20 percent from $2.1 million to under $1.7 million
                                         in First Half 2015, relative to First 
Half 2014. This reflects the results of cost reduction
                                         efforts.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         First Half 2015, impairments of $3.1 
million were recognized. Impairments consisted of:
                                         $2.0 million for the balance of 
deferred pre-stripping of the Briggs Main North Pit,
                                         upon its depletion; $1.0 million 
estimated for the write-down to market value of idled
                                         mining equipment to be sold; and $0.1 
for the balance of stripping activity assets associated
                                         with the Briggs Main North 
Pit.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Exploration
                                         expenses declined from $0.5 million to 
$0.1 million in First Half 2015, relative to First
                                         Half 2014. This reflects reduced 
exploration activities.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.5in; 
text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.25in">&nbsp;</P>

<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">

    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Symbol; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New

<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-

                                         and maintenance expenses declined from 
$0.6 million to nil in First Half 2015, relative
                                         to First Half 2014. This reflects that 
no properties remained on care-and-maintenance
                                         in First Half 2015.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Interest
                                         expense decreased by $0.5 million to 
$2.0 million in First Half 2015, principally as
                                         $4.9 million of debt was voluntarily 
pre-paid in Fourth Quarter 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Losses
                                         on asset disposals were $0.4 million in
First Half 2015 when a redundant haul truck was
                                         sold and $0.3 million in First Half
2014 when other miscellaneous equipment was sold.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         First Half 2014, a foreign exchange 
gain of $2.3 million was realized and recognized
                                         when a debt denominated in Canadian 
dollars was refinanced and pre-paid. There was no
                                         similar transaction in First Half 
2015.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Other
                                         income was $0.1 million in First Half 
2015 and an immaterial amount in First Half 2014.
                                         The former income resulted principally 
from a realized gain upon the disposition of a
                                         joint venture 
interest.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0 0pt 0.6in; 
text-align: justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As of June 30, 2015, cash and cash equivalents
were $1.1 million; the cash balance having decreased $1.1 million in the First 
Half 2015. The significant elements underlying
the net decrease of $1.1 million are presented below with comparisons to First 
Half 2014.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Net
                                         cash provided by operating activities 
was $0.9 million in First Half 2015. Cash provided
                                         by operating activities increased $3.2 
million in First Half 2015, relative to First
                                         Half 2014 when $2.3 million was used 
for operating activities. Of this $3.2 million increase,
                                         $3.0 million was attributable to 
changes in working capital and $0.2 million was attributable
                                         to operating results. While trade 
payables were paid down by $1.4 million in First Half
                                         2014, trade payables increased $2.9 
million in First Half 2015 due largely to increased
                                         operating activities at Pinson 
Underground, resulting in a $4.3 million increase in the
                                         cash position. This was partially 
offset by $0.9 million less cash being provided from
                                         reductions in prepaid assets and from a
$0.5 million increase in accounts receivable,
                                         related to current sales by Pinson 
Underground. As to the $0.2 million attributable to
operating results, reduced cash outlays
for interest, G&amp;A, exploration, and care-and-maintenance
                                         expenses contributed cash flow, but 
were largely offset by declining gold prices and
                                         increasing per unit cost of sales, 
exclusive of depreciation.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">$0.6
                                         million was spent principally for mine 
development at Pinson in First Half 2015. $1.9
                                         million was spent principally for pre-
stripping of the Briggs Main North Pit and for
                                         equipment rebuilds at Briggs in First 
Half 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Nil
                                         and $0.7 million were spent for 
stripping activity assets at Briggs in First Half 2015
                                         and First Half 2014, 
respectively.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         First Half 2015, the surety holding 
collateral for outstanding reclamation bonds agreed
                                         to lower the overall collateral 
requirement to 25 percent of the face amount of the bonds,
                                         essentially returning $0.3 million of 
collateral that had been tied to the Reward and
                                         Clover properties sold in Fourth 
Quarter 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         First Half 2014, investments sold led 
to the realization of $0.1 million. There were
                                         no similar sales in First Half 2015. 
The investments sold were principally stock in other
                                         mining companies acquired in exchange 
for joint venture or property option interests.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">Proceeds
                                         from the sale of assets provided $0.2 
million in First Half 2015 and $0.9 million in
                                         First Half 2014. Miscellaneous assets 
were sold in First Half 2015, and certain mineral
rights in Montana, certain royalty 
interests, and miscellaneous other assets were sold
                                         in First Half 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">The
                                         note placed with Waterton in First Half
2014 provided $21.3 million, refinancing the
                                         note previously provided by Sprott, 
$15.6 million of principal, and other current obligations.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt"><TR STYLE="vertical-
align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"><FONT STYLE="font-
family: Symbol">&middot;</FONT></TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">In
                                         First Half 2015, $1.9 million of cash 
was used to service finance leases and equipment
                                         notes, and $1.9 million was used for 
this in First Half 2014.</TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align:

justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The Company&rsquo;s material undiscounted
contractual obligations as of June 30, 2015 follow.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>&nbsp;</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As of June 30, 2015 and December 31, 2014,
the Company had no outstanding off-balance sheet arrangements.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B><I>Liquidity and Capital Resources</I></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Atna expects that cash requirements over
the next 12 months can be met with cash flow from the Briggs and Pinson 
operations and existing cash, as supplemented by equipment
financings, asset sales, and the refinancing of debt. The Company&rsquo;s recent
forecasts indicate that supplemental financing
will be required to repay the Waterton Note payable in January of 2016. The 
degree to which this debt can be paid-down and the
amount of a subsequent refinancing are largely contingent upon Pinson 
Underground and Briggs realizing operating cash flow targets.
Financing requirements or the ability to raise additional funds may be affected 
by the future price of gold and any unforeseen
or prolonged production disruptions at either mine. The Company may be required 
to seek additional liquidity from the issuance
of debt, convertible bonds, or equity; new lines of credit; asset sales; merger;
amalgamation; or by combinations of these. There
is no assurance that one or more of these financing activities will be 
successful, in which case, the Company&rsquo;s ability
to continue as a going concern may be in doubt.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Capital requirements in 2015 are expected
to be minimal at Briggs and development requirements at Pinson are expected to 
be funded from operations. No material spending
is expected for the Mag Pit or Columbia projects.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Past cash requirements were met through
the use of a combination of operating cash flows, asset sales, and debt and 
equity financings. Please see annual report on Form
20-F for 2014 for descriptions of historical financings.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As of June 30, 2015, the Company had negative
net working capital, current assets less current liabilities, of ($10.7) 
million. $19.1 million of debt is due on January 31,
2016 under the Company&rsquo;s principal credit agreement, and this debt must be
paid-down and/or refinanced by that date. An
increase in accounts payable and accrued liabilities contributed $2.9 million to
cash flows in First Half 2015, however $2.7 million
of this resulted from an increase in business activities and payables at the 
Pinson Underground. Current assets as of June 30,
2015 included recoverable gold inventories of approximately 17,100 ounces at 
Briggs having a recoverable value of $16.2 million.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>

    <DIV STYLE="margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif"><B>ATNA RESOURCES LTD.</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt"><FONT 
STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"><B>For
    the Quarter ended June 30, 2015</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Operating cash flows provided $0.9 million
in First Half 2015. In the balance of 2015, we expect to further ramp-up 
production at Pinson Underground, increase efficiencies
and improve cost performance at Pinson Underground, ramp-down crushing 
activities at Briggs, and continue processing operations
at Briggs. We suspended mining operations at Briggs in July, 2015. The Company 
is expected to produce 45,000 to 55,000 contained
ounces of gold in 2015. Briggs and Pinson Underground are expected to provide 
improved, positive, net operating cash flows, in
the second half of 2015. In both cases, operating cash flows will be enhanced by
prior investments in development, equipment,
inventory, and other assets. Capital spending at Briggs in 2015 is expected to 
be immaterial. Capital spending at Pinson in 2015
is expected to be between $2.0 million and $2.5 million, principally for 
vertical spiral development, long-term lateral development,
and vent raises.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><U>Financing Transactions</U></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><I><U>Equity Issuance</U>:</I></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">No warrants and few options were exercised
in First Half 2015. Options and Restricted Share Units 
(&ldquo;RSU&rsquo;s&rdquo;) are granted and issued in accordance with the
Company&rsquo;s compensation plans. Exercises of warrants and options and 
issuances of RSU&rsquo;s are summarized in the table
below. A roll-forward of the Company&rsquo;s common shares outstanding during 
the first half of 2015 follows.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="border-collapse: collapse; width:

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">As of July 31, 2015; 209,771,801 common
shares were outstanding.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><I><U>Debt</U>: </I></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><I>&nbsp;</I></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">In First Quarter 2015, equipment-financing
notes of $0.1 million were issued for an equipment rebuild. Principal repayments
for finance leases and equipment-financing notes
aggregated $1.9 million in First Half 2015.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">On January 31, 2014, the Company entered
into the Waterton Loan. The Company used this new $22.0 million credit facility 
to pay the current liability due to Sprott of
approximately C$18.1 million, inclusive of early repayment and other fees, and 
the balance was used for general working capital
purposes including a reduction in trade payables. The Waterton Loan is a non-
revolving, senior secured facility, that bears interest
at a coupon rate of 10 percent per annum and matures on the earlier of (i) 
January 31, 2016 and (ii) the date all amounts owing
under the credit facility are voluntarily or mandatorily (as in the case of the 
facility having been accelerated in the event
of a default) prepaid in full, without a repayment penalty. On the maturity 
date, Atna will pay to Waterton (i) a cash fee equal
to 5 percent of the original credit facility and (ii) an additional cash fee 
equal to 5 percent of the credit facility less the
$4.9 million prepayment made during the first 12 months of the Waterton Loan. As
consideration for structuring the credit facility,
Atna paid to Waterton a cash structuring fee of US$440,000 and issued to 
Waterton 10,000,000 non-transferable common share purchase
warrants, which warrants were cancelled in November 2014. Certain assets owned 
directly by Canyon Resources Corp., CR Briggs Corporation,
CR Montana Corporation, and Atna Resources Inc. have been pledged as security 
under the Waterton Loan. Covenants restrict equipment
financings to $12 million and require Waterton&rsquo;s consent for material 
asset sales. The Waterton Loan also precludes additional
borrowings and guarantees of debt, except for Permitted Debt and Liens, and 
allows early prepayments without incurrence of a prepayment
penalty.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>

    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt"><FONT STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"><B>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</TD></TR>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><U>Investing Transactions</U></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><I><U>Disposition of Assets</U></I>:</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Proceeds from the sale of assets provided
$0.2 million in First Half 2015.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><I><U>Capital Expenditures</U></I>:</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Cash expended for mine development and
capital purchases in First Half 2015 and First Half 2014 was $0.6 million and 
$1.9 million, respectively. The 2015 capital expenditures
were principally for development of Pinson Underground, and the 2014 
expenditures were principally for pre-stripping of the Briggs
Main North Pit and equipment rebuilds at Briggs. Nil and $0.7 million, 
respectively, were expended in First Half 2015 and First
Half 2014 for stripping activity assets at Briggs.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Capital expenditures are approved for
expenditure by the Company on a case-by-case basis, and capital spending may be 
modified over time based on judgments as to potential
benefits, project requirements and the availability of funds.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align:

outstanding as of June 30, 2015.</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><U>Surety Bonds</U></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Atna is working with a surety company
to provide bonds for its operations. Collateral is posted with this company to 
cover new or increased bond requirements. All surety
bonds are subject to annual review and adjustment and additional permitting,
extension of mine life, areas of mining activity
and changes in the regulatory environment affect bond requirements.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">In First Quarter 2015, the BLM released
the bonds previously held for the Reward and Clover properties, these properties
having been sold in November 2014. Bonds of $1.0
million were retired and the surety provided a collateral refund of $0.3 
million.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The Company has posted reclamation / surety
bonds and a minor cash-bond for Briggs in the amount of $4.5 million. Restricted
cash held as collateral by the surety and a government
agency amounts to $1.1 million.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">Bonds in place for Pinson total $1.7 million.
The Company has placed $0.4 million into a collateral account related to the 
Pinson surety bonds.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">The Company has on deposit with the MDEQ
$2.4 million in an interest-bearing account for reclamation at the Kendall Mine.
The Company has placed an additional surety bond
of $0.2 million with the MDEQ. The surety of the latter bond is holding $0.1 
million in collateral.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">There is an outstanding surety bond for
Columbia of $0.1 million, associated with a minor amount of collateral.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0pt 0; text-align: 
justify">&nbsp;</P>
